natural problem: If I have a $4\times 4$ chess board, in how many ways can I place four distinct pawns on the board such that each column and row of the board contains no more than one pawn?
natural solution: Because our chess board is $4 \times 4$, there must be exactly one pawn in each column and each row. Consider the ways to place one pawn in each row. In the first row, there are four potential spots for a pawn.
However, no matter where we place the pawn, it takes up one column.
So, in the second row, there are only three potential spots for a pawn.
Similarly, there are two spots in the third row and only one in the fourth.
Thus, there are $4\cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 = 24$ ways in which we can place the pawns.
Now, because each pawn is distinct, we have four possible pawns to place in the first slot, three in the second, two in the fourth, and one in the last.
So there are $24$ possible orderings of the pawns. Our final answer is thus $24^2 = \boxed{576}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chess_board :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool" and pawn_positions :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card (UNIV :: nat set) = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>row col. chess_board row col \<longleftrightarrow> (row, col) \<in> pawn_positions"
and h2 : "\<forall>row col1 col2. chess_board row col1 \<and> chess_board row col2 \<longrightarrow> col1 = col2"
and h3 : "\<forall>col row1 row2. chess_board row1 col \<and> chess_board row2 col \<longrightarrow> row1 = row2"
shows  "card pawn_positions = 576"
a_0.formal solution:

 Because our chess board is $4 \times 4$, there must be exactly one pawn in each column and each row. Consider the ways to place one pawn in each row. In the first row, there are four potential spots for a pawn.
 However, no matter where we place the pawn, it takes up one column.

 Similarly, there are two spots in the third row and only one in the fourth.
 Thus, there are $4\cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 = 24$ ways in which we can place the pawns.
 Now, because each pawn is distinct, we have four possible pawns to place in the first slot, three in the second, two in the fourth, and one in the last.
 So there are $24$ possible orderings of the pawns. Our final answer is thus $24^2 = \boxed{576}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes chess_board :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool" and pawn_positions :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card (UNIV :: nat set) = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>row col. chess_board row col \<longleftrightarrow> (row, col) \<in> pawn_positions"
and h2 : "\<forall>row col1 col2. chess_board row col1 \<and> chess_board row col2 \<longrightarrow> col1 = col2"
and h3 : "\<forall>col row1 row2. chess_board row1 col \<and> chess_board row2 col \<longrightarrow> row1 = row2"
shows  "card pawn_positions = 576"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There is a 4x4 chessboard with pawns placed on it. Each row and column can have at most one pawn. If the number of possible pawn positions is represented by the set `pawn_positions`, find the total number of unique pawn arrangements on the chessboard. The final answer is 576.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chessboard :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n m. chessboard n m = (if n = 4 \<and> m = 4 then 1 else 0)"
shows  "card {p :: (nat \<times> nat) set. finite p \<and> card p = 4 \<and> (\<forall>(x, y) \<in> p. chessboard x y = 1) \<and> (\<forall>x \<in> {1..4}. \<exists>!(y :: nat). (x, y) \<in> p) \<and> (\<forall>y \<in> {1..4}. \<exists>!(x :: nat). (x, y) \<in> p)} = 576"
a_1.formal solution:

 Now, because each pawn is distinct, we have four possible pawns to place in the first slot, three in the second, two in the fourth, and one in the last.
 So there are $24$ possible orderings of the pawns. Our final answer is thus $24^2 = \boxed{576}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes chessboard :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n m. chessboard n m = (if n = 4 \<and> m = 4 then 1 else 0)"
shows  "card {p :: (nat \<times> nat) set. finite p \<and> card p = 4 \<and> (\<forall>(x, y) \<in> p. chessboard x y = 1) \<and> (\<forall>x \<in> {1..4}. \<exists>!(y :: nat). (x, y) \<in> p) \<and> (\<forall>y \<in> {1..4}. \<exists>!(x :: nat). (x, y) \<in> p)} = 576"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a 4x4 chessboard, there is exactly one special cell marked with a 1, and the rest are marked with a 0. How many ways are there to select a set of 4 cells such that each row and each column has exactly one cell in the set? The final answer is 576.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chess_board :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool" and pawns :: "nat \<times> nat set"
assumes h0 : "card pawns = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> chess_board x y \<longleftrightarrow> (x, y) \<in> pawns"

and h3 : "\<forall>y. card {(x, y) | x. (x, y) \<in> pawns} \<le> 1"
shows  "card {pawns | pawns. \<forall>x y. x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> chess_board x y \<longleftrightarrow> (x, y) \<in> pawns
                              \<and> (\<forall>x. card {(x, y) | y. (x, y) \<in> pawns} \<le> 1)
                              \<and> (\<forall>y. card {(x, y) | x. (x, y) \<in> pawns} \<le> 1)} = 576"
a_4.formal solution:

 Now, because each pawn is distinct, we have four possible pawns to place in the first slot, three in the second, two in the fourth, and one in the last.
 So there are $24$ possible orderings of the pawns. Our final answer is thus $24^2 = \boxed{576}$.
 *)

and h2 : "\<forall>x. card {(x, y) | y. (x, y) \<in> pawns} \<le> 1"
and h3 : "\<forall>y. card {(x, y) | x. (x, y) \<in> pawns} \<le> 1"
shows  "card {pawns | pawns. \<forall>x y. x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> chess_board x y \<longleftrightarrow> (x, y) \<in> pawns

and h1 : "\<forall> i. (\<Sum>j \<in> {1..4}. chess_board i j) \<le> 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> j. (\<Sum>i \<in> {1..4}. chess_board i j) \<le> 1"
shows  "(\<Sum>i \<in> {1..4}. \<Sum>j \<in> {1..4}. chess_board i j) = 576"

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chess_board :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool" and pawns :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card pawns = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>r c. chess_board r c \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!p. p \<in> pawns \<and> row p = r \<and> col p = c)"
and h2 : "\<forall>r c. chess_board r c \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>p1 p2. p1 \<in> pawns \<and> p2 \<in> pawns \<and> row p1 = row p2 \<and> col p1 = col p2 \<longrightarrow> p1 = p2)"
and h3 : "\<forall>r c. chess_board r c \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>p. p \<in> pawns \<and> row p = r \<and> col p = c \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!p'. p' \<in> pawns \<and> row p' = r + 1 \<and> col p' = c + 1))"
shows  "card {pawns. \<forall>r c. chess_board r c \<and> pawns \<in> {p. p \<in> pawns \<and> row p = r \<and> col p = c}} = 576"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If I have a $4\times 4$ chess board, in how many ways can I place four distinct pawns on the board such that each column and row of the board contains no more than one pawn? The final Answer is 576
 ### Proof
 Because our chess board is $4 \times 4$, there must be exactly one pawn in each column and each row. Consider the ways to place one pawn in each row. In the first row, there are four potential spots for a pawn.
 However, no matter where we place the pawn, it takes up one column.
 So, in the second row, there are only three potential spots for a pawn.
 Similarly, there are two spots in the third row and only one in the fourth.
 Thus, there are $4\cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 = 24$ ways in which we can place the pawns.
 Now, because each pawn is distinct, we have four possible pawns to place in the first slot, three in the second, two in the fourth, and one in the last.
 So there are $24$ possible orderings of the pawns. Our final answer is thus $24^2 = \boxed{576}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes chess_board :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool" and pawns :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card pawns = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>r c. chess_board r c \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!p. p \<in> pawns \<and> row p = r \<and> col p = c)"
and h2 : "\<forall>r c. chess_board r c \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>p1 p2. p1 \<in> pawns \<and> p2 \<in> pawns \<and> row p1 = row p2 \<and> col p1 = col p2 \<longrightarrow> p1 = p2)"
and h3 : "\<forall>r c. chess_board r c \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>p. p \<in> pawns \<and> row p = r \<and> col p = c \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!p'. p' \<in> pawns \<and> row p' = r + 1 \<and> col p' = c + 1))"
shows  "card {pawns. \<forall>r c. chess_board r c \<and> pawns \<in> {p. p \<in> pawns \<and> row p = r \<and> col p = c}} = 576"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: On a chessboard, there are 4 distinct pawns placed such that for each pawn, there is exactly one other pawn one row above and one column to the right of it. How many different ways can the pawns be arranged on the chessboard? The final answer is 576.

and h2 : "\<forall>i j k l. (i, j) \<in> pawns \<and> (k, l) \<in> pawns \<longrightarrow> (i = k \<longrightarrow> j \<noteq> l) \<and> (j = l \<longrightarrow> i \<noteq> k)"

(i, j) \<in> pawns \<and> (k, l) \<in> pawns \<longrightarrow> (i = k \<longrightarrow> j \<noteq> l) \<and> (j = l \<longrightarrow> i \<noteq> k))} = 576"
a_9.formal solution:

 Now, because each pawn is distinct, we have four possible pawns to place in the first slot, three in the second, two in the fourth, and one in the last.
 So there are $24$ possible orderings of the pawns. Our final answer is thus $24^2 = \boxed{576}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes chess_board :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool" and pawns :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card pawns = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. (i, j) \<in> pawns \<longrightarrow> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 4 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 4"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j k l. (i, j) \<in> pawns \<and> (k, l) \<in> pawns \<longrightarrow> (i = k \<longrightarrow> j \<noteq> l) \<and> (j = l \<longrightarrow> i \<noteq> k)"
shows  "card {pawns. \<forall>i j. (i, j) \<in> pawns \<longrightarrow> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 4 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 4 \<and> (\<forall>i j k l. (i, j) \<in> pawns \<and> (k, l) \<in> pawns \<longrightarrow> (i = k \<longrightarrow> j \<noteq> l) \<and> (j = l \<longrightarrow> i \<noteq> k))} = 576"
